questions.question: This is the first time I …………………. that song.
questions.description: We use a present perfect tense in sentences constructed with ‘this is the first / second / third / last time’.

questions.question: Sorry, I am late. .....................… long?
questions.description: The present perfect continuous tense is used to talk about actions and situations that started in the past and have continued up to the present.

questions.question: Alice ……………….. ten minutes ago.
questions.description: We use the simple past tense to say that something happened sometime ago.

questions.question: I ..................... there for three months.
questions.description: The present perfect and present perfect continuous tenses are used with the time expressions since and for.

questions.question: I think the baby ………………. enough – I will wake her up.
How long ..................... English?
questions.description: The present perfect continuous tense is used to talk about actions and situations that started in the past and have continued up to the present.

questions.question: The Chinese ……………… paper.
questions.description: The simple past tense is the normal tense for talking about finished events in the past.

questions.question: I …………………. James yet.
questions.description: In American English, both the simple past and the present perfect tense are used with indefinite past time adverbs already, yet, ever and before.

questions.question: I ………………… two books since morning.
questions.description: We use the present perfect to say that something has happened several times up to the present.

questions.question: We .....................… each other since
questions.description: The present perfect is often used to talk about how long present situations have lasted.

questions.question: I ……………… the bell several times, but nobody opened the door.
questions.description: The simple past is the normal tense for talking about repeated past actions.

questions.question: …………………. you read the Bible?
questions.description: The present perfect is often used to say that a finished action is connected to the present in some way. If you have read the Bible, you know the Bible.
